mainmatter.p: This is an introductory textbook to univalent mathematics and homotopy type theory, a mathematical foundation that takes advantage of the structural nature of mathematical definitions and constructions.
This post discuss the identity types in type theory. Refer to Introduction to Homotopy Type Theory.

How can we think of equality in type theory? Mentioned before, given a type AAAA and two its elements a,b:Aa,b:Aa,b:Aa,b:A we can define a new type a=_Aba=Aba=_Aba=A​b which is called the identity type. In this case, a term of a=_Aba=Aba=_Aba=A​b is said to be a witness of the equality of aaaa and bbbb. And this witness is itself a type. We can then define their equality. This gives every type a groupoid structure.
The identity type is an inductive type, generated by just a reflexivity identification that providing an equality of a term with itself.

Consider a type AAAA and let a:Aa:Aa:Aa:A be an element. The identity type of AAAA at aaaa is an inductive family of types a=_Axa=Axa=_Axa=A​x indexed by x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A. \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash a=_Ax \space \text {type} } Γ⊢a:AΓ,x:A⊢a=Ax type \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash a=_Ax \space \text {type} } Γ,x:A⊢a=A​x typeΓ⊢a:A​ The only constructor is the refl: \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {refl} _a:a=_Ax } Γ⊢a:AΓ⊢refla:a=Ax \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {refl} _a:a=_Ax } Γ⊢refla​:a=A​xΓ⊢a:A​

tree.mainmatter: The induction principle of the identity type states that for any type family P(x,p)P(x,p)P(x,p)P(x,p) indexed by x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A and p:a=_Axp:a=Axp:a=_Axp:a=A​x, \text {ind-eq}_{ a } :P(a, \text {refl} _a) \to (x:A) \to (p:a=_Ax) \to P(x,p) ind-eqa:P(a,refla)→(x:A)→(p:a=Ax)→P(x,p) \text {ind-eq}_{ a } :P(a, \text {refl} _a) \to (x:A) \to (p:a=_Ax) \to P(x,p) ind-eqa​:P(a,refla​)→(x:A)→(p:a=A​x)→P(x,p) satisfies \text {ind-eq}_{ a } (u,a, \text {refl} _a) \equiv uind-eqa(u,a,refla)≡u\text {ind-eq}_{ a } (u,a, \text {refl} _a) \equiv uind-eqa​(u,a,refla​)≡u where u:P(a, \text {refl} _a)u:P(a,refla)u:P(a, \text {refl} _a)u:P(a,refla​). Formally we can write: \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A, \quad \Gamma ,x:A,p:a=_Ax \vdash P(x,p) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind-eq}_{ a } (a, \text {refl} _a): P(a, \text {refl} _a) \to (x:A) \to (p:a=_Ax) \to P(x,p) } \text {eq-elim} Γ⊢a:A,Γ,x:A,p:a=Ax⊢P(x,p) typeΓ⊢ind-eqa(a,refla):P(a,refla)→(x:A)→(p:a=Ax)→P(x,p)eq-elim \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A, \quad \Gamma ,x:A,p:a=_Ax \vdash P(x,p) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind-eq}_{ a } (a, \text {refl} _a): P(a, \text {refl} _a) \to (x:A) \to (p:a=_Ax) \to P(x,p) } \text {eq-elim} Γ⊢ind-eqa​(a,refla​):P(a,refla​)→(x:A)→(p:a=A​x)→P(x,p)Γ⊢a:A,Γ,x:A,p:a=A​x⊢P(x,p) type​eq-elim \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A, \quad \Gamma ,x:A,p:a=_Ax \vdash P(x,p) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma ,u:P(a, \text {refl} _a) \vdash \text {ind-eq}_{ a } (u,a, \text {refl} _a) \equiv u:P(a, \text {refl} _a) } \text {eq-comp} Γ⊢a:A,Γ,x:A,p:a=Ax⊢P(x,p) typeΓ,u:P(a,refla)⊢ind-eqa(u,a,refla)≡u:P(a,refla)eq-comp \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A, \quad \Gamma ,x:A,p:a=_Ax \vdash P(x,p) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma ,u:P(a, \text {refl} _a) \vdash \text {ind-eq}_{ a } (u,a, \text {refl} _a) \equiv u:P(a, \text {refl} _a) } \text {eq-comp} Γ,u:P(a,refla​)⊢ind-eqa​(u,a,refla​)≡u:P(a,refla​)Γ⊢a:A,Γ,x:A,p:a=A​x⊢P(x,p) type​eq-comp

mainmatter.p: A term of a=_Axa=Axa=_Axa=A​x is called a identification of aaaa and xxxx, or the path from aaaa to xxxx.

tree.mainmatter: We can form an identity type with variables of AAAA. \Gamma ,x:A,y:A \vdash x=_Ay \space \text {type} Γ,x:A,y:A⊢x=Ay type \Gamma ,x:A,y:A \vdash x=_Ay \space \text {type} Γ,x:A,y:A⊢x=A​y type with the following introduction rule: \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash x:A }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash \text {refl} _x:x=_Ax } Γ,x:A⊢x:AΓ,x:A⊢reflx:x=Ax \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash x:A }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash \text {refl} _x:x=_Ax } Γ,x:A⊢reflx​:x=A​xΓ,x:A⊢x:A​ and similarly the elimination rule and computation rule.

mainmatter.p: The identifications can be concatenated and inverted, which implies the transitivity and symmetry of the identity type.

Let AAAA be a type. The Concatenation operation is defined: \text {concat} : (x:A) \to (y:A) \to (z:A) \to (x=_Ay) \to (y=_Az) \to (x=_Az) concat:(x:A)→(y:A)→(z:A)→(x=Ay)→(y=Az)→(x=Az) \text {concat} : (x:A) \to (y:A) \to (z:A) \to (x=_Ay) \to (y=_Az) \to (x=_Az) concat:(x:A)→(y:A)→(z:A)→(x=A​y)→(y=A​z)→(x=A​z)

tree.mainmatter: We can first construct: f(x):(y:A) \to (x=_Ay) \to (z:A) \to (y=_Az) \to (x=_Az) f(x):(y:A)→(x=Ay)→(z:A)→(y=Az)→(x=Az) f(x):(y:A) \to (x=_Ay) \to (z:A) \to (y=_Az) \to (x=_Az) f(x):(y:A)→(x=A​y)→(z:A)→(y=A​z)→(x=A​z) For any x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A, it suffices to construct f(x,x, \text {refl} _x) : (z:A) \to (x=_Az) \to (x=_Az) f(x,x,reflx):(z:A)→(x=Az)→(x=Az) f(x,x, \text {refl} _x) : (z:A) \to (x=_Az) \to (x=_Az) f(x,x,reflx​):(z:A)→(x=A​z)→(x=A​z) That is the identity function \lambda z. \text {id} _{x=_Az}λz.idx=Az\lambda z. \text {id} _{x=_Az}λz.idx=A​z​. Then we can define by induction: f(x) : \equiv \text {ind-eq}_{ x } ( \lambda z. \text {id} ) f(x):≡ind-eqx(λz.id) f(x) : \equiv \text {ind-eq}_{ x } ( \lambda z. \text {id} ) f(x):≡ind-eqx​(λz.id) Finally: \text {concat} _{x,y,z}(p,q) : \equiv f(x,y,p,z,q) concatx,y,z(p,q):≡f(x,y,p,z,q) \text {concat} _{x,y,z}(p,q) : \equiv f(x,y,p,z,q) concatx,y,z​(p,q):≡f(x,y,p,z,q) Or simply we denote \text {concat} (p,q)concat(p,q)\text {concat} (p,q)concat(p,q) as p \cdot qp⋅qp \cdot qp⋅q

mainmatter.p: Let AAAA be a type. The inverse oepration is defined: \text {inv} : (x:A) \to (y:A) \to (x=_Ay) \to (y=_Ax) inv:(x:A)→(y:A)→(x=Ay)→(y=Ax) \text {inv} : (x:A) \to (y:A) \to (x=_Ay) \to (y=_Ax) inv:(x:A)→(y:A)→(x=A​y)→(y=A​x)

tree.mainmatter: By induction, it suffices to construct: \text {inv} (x,x, \text {refl} _x) : (x=_Ax) inv(x,x,reflx):(x=Ax) \text {inv} (x,x, \text {refl} _x) : (x=_Ax) inv(x,x,reflx​):(x=A​x) for any x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A. And trivially we have \text {inv} (x,x, \text {refl} _x) \equiv \text {refl} _xinv(x,x,reflx)≡reflx\text {inv} (x,x, \text {refl} _x) \equiv \text {refl} _xinv(x,x,reflx​)≡reflx​.

mainmatter.p: Let AAAA be a type. These are 3 consecutive identifications p:x=_Ay,q:y=_Az, r:z=_Aw p:x=Ay,q:y=Az,r:z=Aw p:x=_Ay,q:y=_Az, r:z=_Aw p:x=A​y,q:y=A​z,r:z=A​w we define the associator: \text {assoc} : (p,q,r): (p \cdot q) \cdot r = p \cdot (q \cdot r) assoc:(p,q,r):(p⋅q)⋅r=p⋅(q⋅r) \text {assoc} : (p,q,r): (p \cdot q) \cdot r = p \cdot (q \cdot r) assoc:(p,q,r):(p⋅q)⋅r=p⋅(q⋅r)

tree.mainmatter: By definition it suffices to show that \Pi _{(z:A)} \Pi _{(q:x=_Az)} \Pi _{(w:A)} \Pi _{(r:z=_Aw)} ( \text {refl} _x \cdot q) \cdot r = \text {refl} _x \cdot (q \cdot r) Π(z:A)Π(q:x=Az)Π(w:A)Π(r:z=Aw)(reflx⋅q)⋅r=reflx⋅(q⋅r) \Pi _{(z:A)} \Pi _{(q:x=_Az)} \Pi _{(w:A)} \Pi _{(r:z=_Aw)} ( \text {refl} _x \cdot q) \cdot r = \text {refl} _x \cdot (q \cdot r) Π(z:A)​Π(q:x=A​z)​Π(w:A)​Π(r:z=A​w)​(reflx​⋅q)⋅r=reflx​⋅(q⋅r) Let q:x=_Azq:x=Azq:x=_Azq:x=A​z and r:z=_Awr:z=Awr:z=_Awr:z=A​w. By computation rule of identity types \text {refl} _x \cdot q \equiv q reflx⋅q≡q \text {refl} _x \cdot q \equiv q reflx​⋅q≡q Then we can conclude that ( \text {refl} _x \cdot q) \cdot r \equiv q \cdot r (reflx⋅q)⋅r≡q⋅r ( \text {refl} _x \cdot q) \cdot r \equiv q \cdot r (reflx​⋅q)⋅r≡q⋅r similarly \text {refl} _x \cdot (q \cdot r) \equiv q \cdot rreflx⋅(q⋅r)≡q⋅r\text {refl} _x \cdot (q \cdot r) \equiv q \cdot rreflx​⋅(q⋅r)≡q⋅r. Hence we have the left and right side ( \text {refl} _x \cdot q) \cdot r = \text {refl} _x \cdot (q \cdot r) (reflx⋅q)⋅r=reflx⋅(q⋅r) ( \text {refl} _x \cdot q) \cdot r = \text {refl} _x \cdot (q \cdot r) (reflx​⋅q)⋅r=reflx​⋅(q⋅r) are judgementally equal, so we can simply define the associator as \text {assoc} ( \text {refl} _x,q,r) : \equiv \text {refl} _{q \cdot r} assoc(reflx,q,r):≡reflq⋅r \text {assoc} ( \text {refl} _x,q,r) : \equiv \text {refl} _{q \cdot r} assoc(reflx​,q,r):≡reflq⋅r​

mainmatter.p: Let AAAA be a type. We defined the unit law operations for x=_Ayx=Ayx=_Ayx=A​y: \begin {align*} \text {left-unit} & : (x=_Ay) \to ( \text {refl} _x \cdot x = x) \\ \text {right-unit} & : (x=_Ay) \to (x \cdot \text {refl} _y = x) \end {align*} left-unit:(x=Ay)→(reflx⋅x=x)right-unit:(x=Ay)→(x⋅refly=x) \begin {align*} \text {left-unit} & : (x=_Ay) \to ( \text {refl} _x \cdot x = x) \\ \text {right-unit} & : (x=_Ay) \to (x \cdot \text {refl} _y = x) \end {align*} left-unitright-unit​:(x=A​y)→(reflx​⋅x=x):(x=A​y)→(x⋅refly​=x)​

tree.mainmatter: By elimination it suffices to construct: \begin {align*} \text {left-unit}( \text {refl} _x) &: \text {refl} _x \cdot \text {refl} _x = \text {refl} _x \\ \text {right-unit}( \text {refl} _x) &: \text {refl} _x \cdot \text {refl} _x = \text {refl} _x \end {align*} left-unit(reflx):reflx⋅reflx=reflxright-unit(reflx):reflx⋅reflx=reflx \begin {align*} \text {left-unit}( \text {refl} _x) &: \text {refl} _x \cdot \text {refl} _x = \text {refl} _x \\ \text {right-unit}( \text {refl} _x) &: \text {refl} _x \cdot \text {refl} _x = \text {refl} _x \end {align*} left-unit(reflx​)right-unit(reflx​)​:reflx​⋅reflx​=reflx​:reflx​⋅reflx​=reflx​​ In both cases we need only to construct \text {refl} _{ \text {refl} _x}reflreflx\text {refl} _{ \text {refl} _x}reflreflx​​.

mainmatter.p: In previous post, we have seen the definition of natural numbers as an inductive type. In this post, we will see more examples of inductive types, such as unit type, empty type, product type, sum type and etc. Refer to Egbert Rijke's Book.
This section is much more informal than the previous one. Without displaying the inference rules, we will just present the constructor and induction principle of each inductive type.
Just like \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N, other inductive types can be defined by their constructors and induction principles (and computation rules).

ul.li: The constructors specify the structure of the type equipped.
The induction principle specifies the data required to construct a section of an arbitrary type family over the inductive type.
The computation rules specify the behavior of the constructors.

mainmatter.p: The unit type is the simplest inductive type. It has only one constructor, denoted by \star : \textbf {1}⋆:1\star : \textbf {1}⋆:1.

The induction principle of the unit type is trivial. It says that to define a dependent function f: \Pi _{(x: \textbf {1} )} P(x)f:Π(x:1)P(x)f: \Pi _{(x: \textbf {1} )} P(x)f:Π(x:1)​P(x), it suffices to give a value p:P( \star )p:P(⋆)p:P( \star )p:P(⋆). f ( \star ) : \equiv p f(⋆):≡p f ( \star ) : \equiv p f(⋆):≡p
A degenrate inductive type is the empty type. It has no constructor, and its induction principle is trivial. Empty type is connected to the exfalso quodlibet principle in logic.

The empty type is a degenerate inductive type \emptyset∅\emptyset∅ satisfying the following induction principle: \text {ind}_ \emptyset : \Pi _{(x: \emptyset )}P(x) ind∅:Π(x:∅)P(x) \text {ind}_ \emptyset : \Pi _{(x: \emptyset )}P(x) ind∅​:Π(x:∅)​P(x) And a special case is exfalso: \text {exfalso} : \equiv \text {ind}_ \emptyset : \empty \to A exfalso:≡ind∅:∅→A \text {exfalso} : \equiv \text {ind}_ \emptyset : \empty \to A exfalso:≡ind∅​:∅→A which can draw any conclusion.
With the empty type we can define the negation of a type and the proof of negation.

The negation of type AAAA is defined as eg A : \equiv A o \emptyset ¬A:≡A→∅ eg A : \equiv A o \emptyset ¬A:≡A→∅ A type AAAA is said to be empty if and only if eg A¬A eg A¬A is inhabited. ext {empty}(A) : \equiv eg A empty(A):≡¬A ext {empty}(A) : \equiv eg A empty(A):≡¬A
To prove \neg A¬A\neg A¬A, we need to show that AAAA implies a contradiction. In other words, constructing a function of type A \to \emptysetA→∅A \to \emptysetA→∅.

Let AAAA and BBBB be types. The coproduct (disjoint sum) A+BA+BA+BA+B is a typed defined by the following constructors: \text {inl} :A \to A+Binl:A→A+B\text {inl} :A \to A+Binl:A→A+B \text {inr} :B \to A+Binr:B→A+B\text {inr} :B \to A+Binr:B→A+B For any type family indexed by x:A+Bx:A+Bx:A+Bx:A+B, satisfies the following induction principle: \text {ind}_ + : ( \Pi _{(x:A)}P( \text {inl} (x))) \to ( \Pi _{(y:B)}P( \text {inr} (y))) \to \Pi _{(z:A+B)}P(z) ind+:(Π(x:A)P(inl(x)))→(Π(y:B)P(inr(y)))→Π(z:A+B)P(z) \text {ind}_ + : ( \Pi _{(x:A)}P( \text {inl} (x))) \to ( \Pi _{(y:B)}P( \text {inr} (y))) \to \Pi _{(z:A+B)}P(z) ind+​:(Π(x:A)​P(inl(x)))→(Π(y:B)​P(inr(y)))→Π(z:A+B)​P(z) (Note that sometimes we denoted \text {ind}_ + (f,g)ind+(f,g)\text {ind}_ + (f,g)ind+​(f,g) as [f,g][f,g][f,g][f,g]) And the computation rule: \begin {align*} \text {ind}_ + (f,g, \text {inl} (x))& \equiv f(x) \\ \text {ind}_ + (f,g, \text {inr} (y))& \equiv g(y) \end {align*} ind+(f,g,inl(x))≡f(x)ind+(f,g,inr(y))≡g(y) \begin {align*} \text {ind}_ + (f,g, \text {inl} (x))& \equiv f(x) \\ \text {ind}_ + (f,g, \text {inr} (y))& \equiv g(y) \end {align*} ind+​(f,g,inl(x))ind+​(f,g,inr(y))​≡f(x)≡g(y)​ where ffff and gggg are defined: \begin {align*} f&: \Pi _{(x:A)}P( \text {inl} (x)) \\ g&: \Pi _{(y:B)}P( \text {inr} (y)) \end {align*} f:Π(x:A)P(inl(x))g:Π(y:B)P(inr(y)) \begin {align*} f&: \Pi _{(x:A)}P( \text {inl} (x)) \\ g&: \Pi _{(y:B)}P( \text {inr} (y)) \end {align*} fg​:Π(x:A)​P(inl(x)):Π(y:B)​P(inr(y))​ This can be presented by pattern matching to define a function h: \Pi _{(z:A+B)}.P(z)h:Π(z:A+B).P(z)h: \Pi _{(z:A+B)}.P(z)h:Π(z:A+B)​.P(z): \begin {align*} h( \text {inl} (x))&: \equiv f(x) \\ h( \text {inr} (y))&: \equiv g(y) \end {align*} h(inl(x)):≡f(x)h(inr(y)):≡g(y) \begin {align*} h( \text {inl} (x))&: \equiv f(x) \\ h( \text {inr} (y))&: \equiv g(y) \end {align*} h(inl(x))h(inr(y))​:≡f(x):≡g(y)​

frontmatter.title: Inductive Types › Special Case of Coproduct

tree.mainmatter: The special case of coproduct type is also called the sum type. \text {ind}_ + : (A \to X) \to (B \to X) \to (A+B \to X) ind+:(A→X)→(B→X)→(A+B→X) \text {ind}_ + : (A \to X) \to (B \to X) \to (A+B \to X) ind+​:(A→X)→(B→X)→(A+B→X) which is very similar to the elimination rule of disjunction in logic. (P \to Q) \to (R \to Q) \to (P \vee R \to Q) (P→Q)→(R→Q)→(P∨R→Q) (P \to Q) \to (R \to Q) \to (P \vee R \to Q) (P→Q)→(R→Q)→(P∨R→Q)

mainmatter.p: The dependent version of sum type is called the dependent sum type (dependent coproduct) traditionally. Its terms are ordered pairs.
The dependent pair type is a inductive type \Sigma _{(x:A)}B(x)Σ(x:A)B(x)\Sigma _{(x:A)}B(x)Σ(x:A)​B(x) ((x:A) \times B(x)(x:A)×B(x)(x:A) \times B(x)(x:A)×B(x))
Given a type family BBBB over AAAA, we can form the dependent pair type \Sigma _{(x:A)}B(x)Σ(x:A)B(x)\Sigma _{(x:A)}B(x)Σ(x:A)​B(x).
mainmatter.tex: \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash (x:A) \times B(x) \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A typeΓ,x:A⊢B(x) typeΓ⊢(x:A)×B(x) type \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash (x:A) \times B(x) \space \text {type} } Γ⊢(x:A)×B(x) typeΓ⊢A typeΓ,x:A⊢B(x) type​

mainmatter.p: Given a term a:Aa:Aa:Aa:A and a term b(a):B(a)b(a):B(a)b(a):B(a)b(a):B(a), we can form a term \text {pair} (a,b):(x:A) \times B(x)pair(a,b):(x:A)×B(x)\text {pair} (a,b):(x:A) \times B(x)pair(a,b):(x:A)×B(x).
mainmatter.tex: \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A \quad \Gamma \vdash b(a):B(a) }{ \Gamma \vdash (a,b):(x:A) \times B(x) } Γ⊢a:AΓ⊢b(a):B(a)Γ⊢(a,b):(x:A)×B(x) \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A \quad \Gamma \vdash b(a):B(a) }{ \Gamma \vdash (a,b):(x:A) \times B(x) } Γ⊢(a,b):(x:A)×B(x)Γ⊢a:AΓ⊢b(a):B(a)​

mainmatter.p: The elimination rule is formed with two projections. \frac { \Gamma \vdash p:(x:A) \times B(x) }{ \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ A (p):A \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ B (p):B( \text {pr}_ A (p)) \end {align*} } Γ⊢p:(x:A)×B(x)Γ⊢prA(p):AΓ⊢prB(p):B(prA(p)) \frac { \Gamma \vdash p:(x:A) \times B(x) }{ \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ A (p):A \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ B (p):B( \text {pr}_ A (p)) \end {align*} } ΓΓ​⊢prA​(p):A⊢prB​(p):B(prA​(p))​Γ⊢p:(x:A)×B(x)​

p.tex: \frac { \Gamma \vdash x:A \quad \Gamma \vdash y:B(x) }{ \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ A ((x,y))=x:A \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ B ((x,y))=y:B(x) \end {align*} } Γ⊢x:AΓ⊢y:B(x)Γ⊢prA((x,y))=x:AΓ⊢prB((x,y))=y:B(x) \frac { \Gamma \vdash x:A \quad \Gamma \vdash y:B(x) }{ \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ A ((x,y))=x:A \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {pr}_ B ((x,y))=y:B(x) \end {align*} } ΓΓ​⊢prA​((x,y))=x:A⊢prB​((x,y))=y:B(x)​Γ⊢x:AΓ⊢y:B(x)​

ul.li: In the special case that B(x) = BB(x)=BB(x) = BB(x)=B is independent of AAAA, this reduces to the product type A \times BA×BA \times BA×B.
In the special case that D \equiv \text {Boolean}D≡BooleanD \equiv \text {Boolean}D≡Boolean, this reduces to a coproduct type.

frontmatter.title: Natural Numbers \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N

mainmatter.p: In previous post, we have seen the basic inference rules of type theory. Now we will see the definition of natural numbers as an inductive type. Refer to HoTT Book and Egbert Rijke's.
In classical mathematics, the Peano axioms are a set of axioms for the natural numbers, an important object in mathematics.
In type theory, the type \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N of natural number is an inductive type. Just like in dependent function type, we need four inference rules to define the natural numbers.

In type theory, natural number is defined using peano encoding. The type \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N is formed by the formation rule: \frac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \mathbb {N} \text {-form} ⊢N typeN-form \frac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \mathbb {N} \text {-form} ⊢N type​N-form

Peano's first axiom postulates the existence of a natural number 0000. The introduction rule for \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N has a 0000 constructor and a successor function. \frac {}{ \vdash0 : \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-0} \quad \frac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-succ} ⊢0:NN-intro-0⊢succ:N→NN-intro-succ \frac {}{ \vdash0 : \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-0} \quad \frac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-succ} ⊢0:N​N-intro-0⊢succ:N→N​N-intro-succ

The elimination rule is actually the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N: In order to show that \forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)∀n:N.P(n)\forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)∀n:N.P(n) holds, it suffices to show that P(0)P(0)P(0)P(0) holds and that \forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n))∀n:N.P(n)→P(succ(n))\forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n))∀n:N.P(n)→P(succ(n)) holds. The type theoretical induction principle is therefore formulated using a type family PPPP over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N: \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &, \, n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S): \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ, n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢p0:P(0)Γ⊢pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n))Γ⊢indN(p0,pS):Π(n:N)P(n)(N-ind) \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &, \, n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S): \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ⊢indN​(p0​,pS​):Π(n:N)​P(n)ΓΓΓ​,n:N⊢P(n) type⊢p0​:P(0)⊢pS​:Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​​(N-ind) The induction principle tells us what we need to do in order to construct a dependent function \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN\text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN​ of type \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n)Π(n:N)P(n)\Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n)Π(n:N)​P(n). We might alternatively write the induction principle as: \frac { \Gamma ,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} : \left (P(0) \to \left ( \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \right ) \to \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \right ) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ,n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢indN:(P(0)→(Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n)))→Π(n:N)P(n))(N-ind) \frac { \Gamma ,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} : \left (P(0) \to \left ( \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \right ) \to \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \right ) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ⊢indN​:(P(0)→(Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n)))→Π(n:N)​P(n))Γ,n:N⊢P(n) type​(N-ind)

The computation rule asserts that the dependent function \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN\text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN​ behaves as expected: \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,m) \equiv \begin {cases} p_0& \text {if }m=0 \\ p_S(n, \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,n))& \text {if }m= \text {succ} (n) \end {cases} }( \mathbb {N} \text {-comp}) Γ,n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢p0:P(0)Γ⊢pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n))indN(p0,pS,m)≡{p0if m=0pS(n,indN(p0,pS,n))if m=succ(n)(N-comp) \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,m) \equiv \begin {cases} p_0& \text {if }m=0 \\ p_S(n, \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,n))& \text {if }m= \text {succ} (n) \end {cases} }( \mathbb {N} \text {-comp}) indN​(p0​,pS​,m)≡{p0​pS​(n,indN​(p0​,pS​,n))​if m=0if m=succ(n)​ΓΓΓ​,n:N⊢P(n) type⊢p0​:P(0)⊢pS​:Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​​(N-comp)
Now let's use the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N to perform some basic construction over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N.

frontmatter.title: Addition over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N

mainmatter.p: We define addition over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N using the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N. \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) addN:N→(N→N) \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) addN​:N→(N→N) which satisfies the following specification: \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (n, 0)&: \equiv n \\ \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))&: \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN(n,0):≡naddN(m,succ(n)):≡succ(addN(m,n)) \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (n, 0)&: \equiv n \\ \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))&: \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN​(n,0)addN​(m,succ(n))​:≡n:≡succ(addN​(m,n))​ abbreviated as m + nm+nm + nm+n for \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)addN(m,n)\text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)addN​(m,n).

tree.mainmatter: We construct the additon by perform induction over the second variable nnnn. That is, to construct an element m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} m:N⊢addN(m):N→N m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} m:N⊢addN​(m):N→N The context \Gamma \equiv m: \mathbb {N}Γ≡m:N\Gamma \equiv m: \mathbb {N}Γ≡m:N is fixed. Therefore we need to construct: \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} \end {align*} Γ⊢add-zeroN(m):NΓ⊢add-succN(m):N→N \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} \end {align*} ΓΓ​⊢add-zeroN​(m):N⊢add-succN​(m):N→N​ The \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N}add-zeroN\text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N}add-zeroN​ is defined to be identity function trivially. To see how \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN\text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN​ is defined, we need to perform induction: \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))& \equiv \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {succ} (n)) \\ & \equiv \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n, \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \\ & \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN(m,succ(n))≡indN(add-zeroN(m),add-succN(m),succ(n))≡add-succN(m,n,addN(m,n))≡succ(addN(m,n)) \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))& \equiv \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {succ} (n)) \\ & \equiv \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n, \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \\ & \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN​(m,succ(n))​≡indN​(add-zeroN​(m),add-succN​(m),succ(n))≡add-succN​(m,n,addN​(m,n))≡succ(addN​(m,n))​ Hence \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN\text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN​ is defined as: \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n,x) \equiv \text {succ} (x) add-succN(m,n,x)≡succ(x) \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n,x) \equiv \text {succ} (x) add-succN​(m,n,x)≡succ(x) A formal construction of \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN\text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN​ is as follows: \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \quad \dfrac { \dfrac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash m: \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \equiv m: \mathbb {N} } \quad \dfrac { \text {Block-1}}{ m: mainmatter.p: Recall the definition of addition function \text {add}: \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} )add:N→(N→N)\text {add}: \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} )add:N→(N→N) satisfying the specification: \begin {align*} m + 0 & : \equiv m \\ m + \text {succ} (n) & : \equiv \text {succ} (m + n) \end {align*} m+0:≡mm+succ(n):≡succ(m+n) \begin {align*} m + 0 & : \equiv m \\ m + \text {succ} (n) & : \equiv \text {succ} (m + n) \end {align*} m+0m+succ(n)​:≡m:≡succ(m+n)​ Such definition is enough to characterize the addition function. Because it postulates te behavior of \text {add}_ \mathbb {N}addN\text {add}_ \mathbb {N}addN​ at the constructor of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N

More generally, we can define a dependent function f: \Pi n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)f:Πn:N.P(n)f: \Pi n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)f:Πn:N.P(n) by induction on nnnn using \begin {align*} p_0 & : P(0) \\ p_S & : \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} p0:P(0)pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n)) \begin {align*} p_0 & : P(0) \\ p_S & : \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} p0​pS​​:P(0):Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​ Just present the definition by writing \begin {align*} f(0) & : \equiv p_0 \\ f( \text {succ} (n)) & : \equiv p_S(n,f(n)) \end {align*} f(0):≡p0f(succ(n)):≡pS(n,f(n)) \begin {align*} f(0) & : \equiv p_0 \\ f( \text {succ} (n)) & : \equiv p_S(n,f(n)) \end {align*} f(0)f(succ(n))​:≡p0​:≡pS​(n,f(n))​ ffff is said to be defined by pattern matching on the variable nnnn.

The Fibonacci function is a well-known function in mathematics. It is defined by pattern matching on the variable nnnn as follows: \begin {align*} \text {fib}(0) & : \equiv 0 \\ \text {fib}(1) & : \equiv 1 \\ \text {fib}(n+2) & : \equiv \text {fib}(n) + \text {fib}(n+1) \end {align*} fib(0):≡0fib(1):≡1fib(n+2):≡fib(n)+fib(n+1) \begin {align*} \text {fib}(0) & : \equiv 0 \\ \text {fib}(1) & : \equiv 1 \\ \text {fib}(n+2) & : \equiv \text {fib}(n) + \text {fib}(n+1) \end {align*} fib(0)fib(1)fib(n+2)​:≡0:≡1:≡fib(n)+fib(n+1)​
This is a note on dependent type theory. Refer to HoTT Book and Egbert Rijke's.

Homotopy type theory is a foundational language for mathematics, an alternative to Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory. The set-theoretic foundation has two two layers:
the deductive system of first-order logic
the theory of a particular theory, such as ZFC Type theory itself is a deductive system, which has one basic notation: types. Propositions are identified with types.
Thus, the activity of proving a theorem is identified with constructing a inhabitant of a certain type.
Informally, a deductive system is a collection of rules for deriving judgments. The judgment is considered to be the external of the theory, living in the metatheory.

In first order logic, there is only one kind of judgment: a proposition has a proof. A proposition PPPP gives rise to a judgment "PPPP has a proof". The proposition PPPP lives inside the theory, while the judgment "PPPP has a proof" lives in the metatheory.

In type theory, analogous to first order logic, "PPPP has a proof" is written as "p:Pp:Pp:Pp:P" (Type PPPP has a term pppp). If PPPP is a proposition, then pppp is a witness to the provability of PPPP, or evidence of the truth of PPPP. p:Pp:Pp:Pp:P can also be interpreted as p \in Pp∈Pp \in Pp∈P, but p:Pp:Pp:Pp:P is a judgment while p \in Pp∈Pp \in Pp∈P is a proposition. Working inside type theory we can't write down statements like "if p:Pp:Pp:Pp:P then ..." nor can we disprove the judgment "p:Pp:Pp:Pp:P".

A key difference between type theory and set theory is the equality. The notion of equality in set theory is simply a proposition. Howerver, in type theory, there are two kinds of equality. The first kind is the propositional equality a=_Aba=Aba=_Aba=A​b. This is a proposition The second kind is the judgmental equality a \equiv b:Aa≡b:Aa \equiv b:Aa≡b:A. This is a judgment Two terms a:Aa:Aa:Aa:A and b:Ab:Ab:Ab:A are propositionally equal if you can prove a =_A ba=Aba =_A ba=A​b , or equivalently if you can construct a term h : a =_A bh:a=Abh : a =_A bh:a=A​b.
In type theory there is also a requirement for a judgment-level equality. This is called judgmental equality, meaning "equal by definition".

Judgemental equality of terms is given by the following judgement: \Gamma \vdash a \equiv a':A Γ⊢a≡a′:A \Gamma \vdash a \equiv a':A Γ⊢a≡a′:A aaaa and a'a′a'a′ are judgementally equal terms of type AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ.
Note that the notation \equiv≡\equiv≡ binds more loosely than anything else.

judgments may depend on assumptions of the form x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A where xxxx is a variable and AAAA is a type. And the collection (actually ordered list) of such assumptions is called the context, denoted \GammaΓ\GammaΓ. (from a topological point of view it may be thought of as a parameters space). The role of a context is to declare what hypothetical terms are assumed, along with their types. The notation \vdash⊢\vdash⊢ means making conclusion from assumptions.

Remember the difference between axiom and (inference) rules.
Rules allow us to conclude one judgment from a collection of other judgments.
Axioms are judgments that are assumed to be true without proof.
We start by introduction to Matrin Lof's dependent type theory.
There are four kinds of judgments in Martin Lof's dependent type theory:

ul.li: AAAA is a well-formed type in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} Γ⊢A type \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} Γ⊢A type
AAAA and BBBB are judgmentally equal types in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} Γ⊢A≡B type \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} Γ⊢A≡B type
aaaa is a term of type AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ \Gamma \vdash a : A Γ⊢a:A \Gamma \vdash a : A Γ⊢a:A
aaaa and bbbb are judgmentally equal terms of type AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b : A Γ⊢a≡b:A \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b : A Γ⊢a≡b:A

mainmatter.p:
All judgments are context dependent, and indeed that even the types of the variables in a context may depend on any previous declared variables.
To introduce types dependent on terms, we need the notation of type families.

Consider a type AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ. A family of types over AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ is a type B(x)B(x)B(x)B(x) in context \Gamma , x:AΓ,x:A\Gamma , x:AΓ,x:A. \Gamma , x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} Γ,x:A⊢B(x) type \Gamma , x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} Γ,x:A⊢B(x) type BBBB is a family of types over AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ. Alternatively, we say that B(x)B(x)B(x)B(x) is a type indexed by x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ.
Now we can define a term of a type family, that is, a section of a type family.

Let BBBB be a type family over AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ. A section of BBBB is a term bbbb of type B(x)B(x)B(x)B(x) in context \Gamma ,x:AΓ,x:A\Gamma ,x:AΓ,x:A. \Gamma , x:A \vdash b : B(x) Γ,x:A⊢b:B(x) \Gamma , x:A \vdash b : B(x) Γ,x:A⊢b:B(x) Alternatively, we say that bbbb is a term of B(x)B(x)B(x)B(x) indexed by x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ.

We now ready to present the inference rules for dependent type theory. These rules are known as the structual rules of the theory. There are 6 sets of rules:
Formation contexts, types and terms
Postulating that judgmental equality is an equivalence relation
Vairable conversion
Substitution
Weakening
Generic element

frontmatter.title: Formation of contexts, types and terms

mainmatter.p: The following rules follow from the presuppotion about contexts, types and terms, can be used freely.

li.tex: \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} } Γ,x:A⊢B(x) typeΓ⊢A type \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A typeΓ,x:A⊢B(x) type​

\frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash B \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A≡B typeΓ⊢A typeΓ⊢A≡B typeΓ⊢B type \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash B \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A typeΓ⊢A≡B type​Γ⊢B typeΓ⊢A≡B type​
\frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} } Γ⊢a:AΓ⊢A type \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A typeΓ⊢a:A​

\frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A }{ \Gamma \vdash a:A } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A }{ \Gamma \vdash b:A } Γ⊢a≡b:AΓ⊢a:AΓ⊢a≡b:AΓ⊢b:A \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A }{ \Gamma \vdash a:A } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A }{ \Gamma \vdash b:A } Γ⊢a:AΓ⊢a≡b:A​Γ⊢b:AΓ⊢a≡b:A​

mainmatter.p: Judgmental equality on types and on elements is an equivalence relation simply postulate that these relations are reflexive, symmetric, and transitive:

li.tex: \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma \vdash a \equiv a:A } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A }{ \Gamma \vdash b \equiv a:A } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A \quad \Gamma \vdash b \equiv c:A }{ \Gamma \vdash a \equiv c:A } Γ⊢a:AΓ⊢a≡a:AΓ⊢a≡b:AΓ⊢b≡a:AΓ⊢a≡b:AΓ⊢b≡c:AΓ⊢a≡c:A \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A }{ \Gamma \vdash a \equiv a:A } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A }{ \Gamma \vdash b \equiv a:A } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv b:A \quad \Gamma \vdash b \equiv c:A }{ \Gamma \vdash a \equiv c:A } Γ⊢a≡a:AΓ⊢a:A​Γ⊢b≡a:AΓ⊢a≡b:A​Γ⊢a≡c:AΓ⊢a≡b:AΓ⊢b≡c:A​

\frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A \space \text {type} } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash B \equiv A \space \text {type} } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma \vdash B \equiv C \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \equiv C \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A typeΓ⊢A≡A typeΓ⊢A≡B typeΓ⊢B≡A typeΓ⊢A≡B typeΓ⊢B≡C typeΓ⊢A≡C type \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A \space \text {type} } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash B \equiv A \space \text {type} } \quad \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv B \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma \vdash B \equiv C \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash A \equiv C \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A≡A typeΓ⊢A type​Γ⊢B≡A typeΓ⊢A≡B type​Γ⊢A≡C typeΓ⊢A≡B typeΓ⊢B≡C type​

mainmatter.p: This rule postulates that we can convert the type of a variable to a judgmentally equal type. \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma ,x:A', \Delta \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A,Δ⊢B(x) typeΓ,x:A′,Δ⊢B(x) type \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma ,x:A', \Delta \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} } Γ,x:A′,Δ⊢B(x) typeΓ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A,Δ⊢B(x) type​ Similarly, we can convert judgmental equality of types and terms. We state all of them at once using a generic judgment thesis \mathcal {J}J\mathcal {J}J. \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }{ \Gamma ,x:A', \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }VC Γ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A,Δ⊢JΓ,x:A′,Δ⊢JVC \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }{ \Gamma ,x:A', \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }VC Γ,x:A′,Δ⊢JΓ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A,Δ⊢J​VC

Consider a term f:B(x)f:B(x)f:B(x)f:B(x) indexed by x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ, and we also have a term a:Aa:Aa:Aa:A. We can simultaneously substitute aaaa for all occurrences of xxxx in ffff to obtain a new term f[x:=a]:B(a)f[x:=a]:B(a)f[x:=a]:B(a)f[x:=a]:B(a).

The substitution rule postulates that we can substitute a term for a variable. \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }{ \Gamma , \Delta [x:=a] \vdash \mathcal {J}[x:=a] }S Γ⊢a:AΓ,x:A,Δ⊢JΓ,Δ[x:=a]⊢J[x:=a]S \frac { \Gamma \vdash a:A \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }{ \Gamma , \Delta [x:=a] \vdash \mathcal {J}[x:=a] }S Γ,Δ[x:=a]⊢J[x:=a]Γ⊢a:AΓ,x:A,Δ⊢J​S The notation \Gamma , \Delta [x:=a]Γ,Δ[x:=a]\Gamma , \Delta [x:=a]Γ,Δ[x:=a] means that we substitute aaaa for xxxx in \DeltaΔ\DeltaΔ.

With the substitution rule, we need two more congruence rules to convert judgmental equality of terms and types. \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv a':A \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma , \Delta [x:=a] \vdash B[x:=a] \equiv B[x:=a'] \space \text {type} } Γ⊢a≡a′:AΓ,x:A,Δ⊢B typeΓ,Δ[x:=a]⊢B[x:=a]≡B[x:=a′] type \frac { \Gamma \vdash a \equiv a':A \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma , \Delta [x:=a] \vdash B[x:=a] \equiv B[x:=a'] \space \text {type} } Γ,Δ[x:=a]⊢B[x:=a]≡B[x:=a′] typeΓ⊢a≡a′:AΓ,x:A,Δ⊢B type​ \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash b:A }{ \Gamma , \Delta [x:=a] \vdash b[x:=a] \equiv b[x:=a']:A'[x:=a] \space \text {type} } Γ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A,Δ⊢b:AΓ,Δ[x:=a]⊢b[x:=a]≡b[x:=a′]:A′[x:=a] type \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash b:A }{ \Gamma , \Delta [x:=a] \vdash b[x:=a] \equiv b[x:=a']:A'[x:=a] \space \text {type} } Γ,Δ[x:=a]⊢b[x:=a]≡b[x:=a′]:A′[x:=a] typeΓ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A,Δ⊢b:A​

Let BBBB be a type family over AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ, an a well-formed term a:Aa:Aa:Aa:A, then we say that B[x:=a]B[x:=a]B[x:=a]B[x:=a] is the fiber of BBBB at aaaa, denoted B(a)B(a)B(a)B(a).
Let bbbb a section of BBBB over AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ, then we say that b(a): \equiv b[x:=a]b(a):≡b[x:=a]b(a): \equiv b[x:=a]b(a):≡b[x:=a] is the value of bbbb at aaaa.

The process of expanding the context by a fresh variable of type AAAA is called weakening (by AAAA). Intuitively, weakening is the process of adding a new hypothesis to the context. And the hypothesis will weaken the conclusion.

Weakening rule asserts that we can add a variable to the context. \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma , \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }{ \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }W Γ⊢A typeΓ,Δ⊢JΓ,x:A,Δ⊢JW \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma , \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }{ \Gamma ,x:A, \Delta \vdash \mathcal {J} }W Γ,x:A,Δ⊢JΓ⊢A typeΓ,Δ⊢J​W
Finally, the generic elemets rule ensures that the variables declared in a context.

The rule for the generic element asserts that any hypothetical element x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A in context \Gamma ,x:AΓ,x:A\Gamma ,x:AΓ,x:A is also an element of AAAA in context \Gamma ,x:AΓ,x:A\Gamma ,x:AΓ,x:A. \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash x:A } \delta Γ⊢A typeΓ,x:A⊢x:Aδ \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash x:A } \delta Γ,x:A⊢x:AΓ⊢A type​δ This rule is also called the variable rule.
The next topic is the dependent function type, a fundamental concept of dependent type theory. Simply put, a dependent function type is a function whose type of output may depend on the input.

Consider a section bbbb of a family BBBB over AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ: \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x):B(x) Γ,x:A⊢b(x):B(x) \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x):B(x) Γ,x:A⊢b(x):B(x) Such a section bbbb is an operation or assignment x \mapsto b(x)x↦b(x)x \mapsto b(x)x↦b(x) that assigns to each element x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A to a term b(x):B(x)b(x):B(x)b(x):B(x)b(x):B(x). We may see bbbb as a function takes x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A to b(x):B(x)b(x):B(x)b(x):B(x)b(x):B(x). The function x \mapsto b(x)x↦b(x)x \mapsto b(x)x↦b(x) is called a dependent function. The type of all dependent functions from AAAA to BBBB is called the dependent function type. \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) \text { or } (x:A) \to B(x) Π(x:A)B(x) or (x:A)→B(x) \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) \text { or } (x:A) \to B(x) Π(x:A)​B(x) or (x:A)→B(x)

To introduce a type we need the following four rules:
Formation rule
Introduction rule
Elimination rule
Computation rule Besides these we also need the congruence rule for judgmental equality.

Formation Rule For any type family BBBB over AAAA in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ: \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) \space \text {type} } \Pi Γ,x:A⊢B(x) typeΓ⊢Π(x:A)B(x) typeΠ \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) \space \text {type} } \Pi Γ⊢Π(x:A)​B(x) typeΓ,x:A⊢B(x) type​Π We also require that the operation of forming dependent function types respects judgmental equality. \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \equiv B'(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) \equiv \Pi _{(x:A')}B'(x) \space \text {type} } \Pi \text {-eq} Γ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A⊢B(x)≡B′(x) typeΓ⊢Π(x:A)B(x)≡Π(x:A′)B′(x) typeΠ-eq \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \equiv A' \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B(x) \equiv B'(x) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) \equiv \Pi _{(x:A')}B'(x) \space \text {type} } \Pi \text {-eq} Γ⊢Π(x:A)​B(x)≡Π(x:A′)​B′(x) typeΓ⊢A≡A′ typeΓ,x:A⊢B(x)≡B′(x) type​Π-eq

Introduction Rule (\lambdaλ\lambdaλ-abstraction) In order to construct a dependent function we have to construct a term f(x):B(x)f(x):B(x)f(x):B(x)f(x):B(x) indexed by x:Ax:Ax:Ax:A in context \GammaΓ\GammaΓ: \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x):B(x) }{ \Gamma \vdash \lambda x.b(x): \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) } \lambda Γ,x:A⊢b(x):B(x)Γ⊢λx.b(x):Π(x:A)B(x)λ \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x):B(x) }{ \Gamma \vdash \lambda x.b(x): \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) } \lambda Γ⊢λx.b(x):Π(x:A)​B(x)Γ,x:A⊢b(x):B(x)​λ And the congruence rule: \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x) \equiv b'(x):B(x) }{ \Gamma \vdash \lambda x.b(x) \equiv \lambda x.b'(x): \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) } \lambda \text {-eq} Γ,x:A⊢b(x)≡b′(x):B(x)Γ⊢λx.b(x)≡λx.b′(x):Π(x:A)B(x)λ-eq \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x) \equiv b'(x):B(x) }{ \Gamma \vdash \lambda x.b(x) \equiv \lambda x.b'(x): \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) } \lambda \text {-eq} Γ⊢λx.b(x)≡λx.b′(x):Π(x:A)​B(x)Γ,x:A⊢b(x)≡b′(x):B(x)​λ-eq

Elimination Rule (Evaluation Rule) In order to use dependent function we need to provide an argument of the domain type. \frac { \Gamma \vdash f: \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash f(x):B(x) }ev Γ⊢f:Π(x:A)B(x)Γ,x:A⊢f(x):B(x)ev \frac { \Gamma \vdash f: \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash f(x):B(x) }ev Γ,x:A⊢f(x):B(x)Γ⊢f:Π(x:A)​B(x)​ev Again we require the judgmental equality to be respected: \frac { \Gamma \vdash f \equiv f': \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash f(x) \equiv f'(x):B(x) }ev \text {-eq} Γ⊢f≡f′:Π(x:A)B(x)Γ,x:A⊢f(x)≡f′(x):B(x)ev-eq \frac { \Gamma \vdash f \equiv f': \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash f(x) \equiv f'(x):B(x) }ev \text {-eq} Γ,x:A⊢f(x)≡f′(x):B(x)Γ⊢f≡f′:Π(x:A)​B(x)​ev-eq

Computation Rule (\betaβ\betaβ-reduction) \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x):B(x) }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash ( \lambda y.b(y))(x) \equiv b(x):B(x) } \beta Γ,x:A⊢b(x):B(x)Γ,x:A⊢(λy.b(y))(x)≡b(x):B(x)β \frac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash b(x):B(x) }{ \Gamma ,x:A \vdash ( \lambda y.b(y))(x) \equiv b(x):B(x) } \beta Γ,x:A⊢(λy.b(y))(x)≡b(x):B(x)Γ,x:A⊢b(x):B(x)​β We postulate that all elements of a dependent function type are dependent functions. \frac { \Gamma \vdash f: \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) }{ \Gamma \vdash f \equiv \lambda x.f(x): \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) } \eta Γ⊢f:Π(x:A)B(x)Γ⊢f≡λx.f(x):Π(x:A)B(x)η \frac { \Gamma \vdash f: \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) }{ \Gamma \vdash f \equiv \lambda x.f(x): \Pi _{(x:A)}B(x) } \eta Γ⊢f≡λx.f(x):Π(x:A)​B(x)Γ⊢f:Π(x:A)​B(x)​η
A degenrated case of dependent function type is the ordinary function type.

A special case of \PiΠ\PiΠ-type is the ordinary function type. Using weakening rule we can obtain thee type A \to BA→BA \to BA→B of ordinary function from AAAA to BBBB \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma \vdash B \space \text {type} }{ \dfrac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \Pi _{(x:A)}B \space \text {type} } \Pi }W Γ⊢A typeΓ⊢B typeΓ,x:A⊢B typeΓ⊢Π(x:A)B typeΠW \frac { \Gamma \vdash A \space \text {type} \quad \Gamma \vdash B \space \text {type} }{ \dfrac { \Gamma ,x:A \vdash B \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \Pi _{(x:A)}B \space \text {type} } \Pi }W Γ⊢Π(x:A)​B typeΓ,x:A⊢B type​ΠΓ⊢A typeΓ⊢B type​W A term f: \Pi _{(x:A)}Bf:Π(x:A)Bf: \Pi _{(x:A)}Bf:Π(x:A)​B is an ordinary function. The type A \to BA→BA \to BA→B is defined: A \to B := \Pi _{(x:A)}B A→B:=Π(x:A)B A \to B := \Pi _{(x:A)}B A→B:=Π(x:A)​B The type AAAA is called domain of ffff, and type BBBB is called codomain of ffff. The notation :=:=:=:= here means to make a definition.
